g.text: ineral dust is likely the most abundant aerosol type by
. It affects the climate system in
numerous ways, including by scattering and absorbing
radiation, serving as a nuclei for cloud formation, and fertilizing
atmospheric dust loading have been hypothesized to produce a
substantial radiative forcing of the climate system
dust cycle is itself also highly sensitive to changes in climate
evidenced by global dust deposition being several times larger
during glacial maxima than during interglacials
large variability of the global dust cycle over the observational
This sensitivity to past climate changes raises the question of
how the global dust cycle will respond to projected future climate
changes, and of whether the resulting dust
oppose or enhance those climate changes. However, past assess-
ments of the dust cycle response to future climate changes have
yielded divergent results, and there is no consensus on whether
climate feedback will enhance or oppose future climate
climate feedback is hindered by several uncertainties,
including in future changes to wind and precipitation
the dust radiative effect in the present climate
nature of dust emission parameterizations in global circulation
. These parameterizations generally use so-called pre-
ferential dust source functions that tune emissions to better
functions are invariant to climate, whereas the geological record
shows that source regions are quite sensitive to climate
a source function in simulations of the dust cycle
future climate change could produce large systematic errors
Although interactions between climate and the global dust
cycle remain highly uncertain, recent advances now permit an
order-of-magnitude estimation of the direct dust
back. In particular, a physically based dust emission scheme can
now reproduce the global dust cycle without the use of an
nitrogen and carbon cycles in climate models
nitrogen limitation to more realistically constrain the effects of
constrained the dust direct radiative effect (DRE) in the present
Here, we leverage these advances in order to estimate the direct
climate feedback. We do so by using a simple theoretical
framework that combines constraints on the dust DRE
model simulations of how that DRE is distributed regionally, and
with a series of climate model results on the response of the
change in global dust loading in response to future climate
change. A subset of these simulations use both coupled
and the more physically based dust-
emission parameterization that does not require a source
nd that the global direct dust
back is of the order of a percent of the total physical feedbacks in
the climate system, and that it is approximately an order of
magnitude larger close to source regions, where it could play an
important role in shaping future climate.
retical framework for estimating the dust
climate model simulations. Feedbacks in the climate system are

through interactions with radiation, termed the direct radiative
effect (DRE), and indirectly through interactions with clouds,

. We therefore restrict our discussion to the direct
climate feedback arising from changes in the dust direct
radiative effect only, which is better understood and has a better
A change in global dust loading changes the dust DRE, which
constitutes a radiative forcing. Since the dust DRE is approxi-
mately linear in the global dust loading
radiative forcing at TOA relative to the present-day climate,
) is the global dust loading at a future time

climate feedback is likely to be substantially

Note that some previous studies have de
feedback relative to the local temperature change
are largely advected from upwind locations, and since aerosol
feedbacks do not arise from a local thermodynamic response,
there is less causal relation between temperature and aerosol
loading at a given location. Consequently, de
feedback relative to the local temperature change would not
capture the physical processes (e.g., upwind changes in wind
speed, vegetation, soil moisture, and precipitation) that ultimately
drive local changes in aerosol concentration and radiative effects.
feedback as relative to the change in global surface temperature.
